qas.question: What legislative body confirms FBI directors?
How long is the term of a FBI director?
What made Hoover stop serving as the FBI Director?
Who is the current FBI director?
Who appoints the President of the United States?
What legislative body confirms U.S. presidents?
How long is the term of a U.S. president?
Who was the shortest serving FBI director?
When did FBI Director Comey resign?

context: <b5_0>FBI Directors<b5_0/> are appointed by the <a0_0>President of the United States<a0_0/>. They must be confirmed by the <a1_0><b6_0>United States Senate<b6_0/><a1_0/> and serve a term of office of <a2_0><b7_0>five years<b7_0/><a2_0/>, with a maximum of ten years, if reappointed, unless they resign or are fired by the President before their term ends. <b8_0>J. Edgar Hoover<b8_0/>, appointed by Calvin Coolidge in 1924, was by far the longest-serving director, serving until <a3_0>his death<a3_0/> in 1972. In 1968, Congress passed legislation as part of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act Pub.L. 90–351, June 19, 1968, 82 Stat. 197 that specified a 10-year limit, a maximum of two 5-year terms, for future FBI Directors, as well as requiring Senate confirmation of appointees. As the incumbent, this legislation did not apply to Hoover, only to his successors. The current FBI Director is <a4_0>James B. Comey<a4_0/>, who was appointed in <b9_0>2013<b9_0/> by Barack Obama.
